information: Joe Pyfer has won six of his last seven professional fights, holding a 4-1 record within the UFC. His most recent victory was a first-round knockout of Marc-Andre Barriault at UFC 303, which earned him a Performance of the Night bonus. Pyfer had to withdraw from the originally scheduled fight against Gastelum in Mexico due to an illness.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 3–4 months, until UFC 316 fight night (likely late Aug–Sep 2025).
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Pyfer is scheduled to face Kelvin Gastelum at UFC 316; if nothing changes, the bout happens and Pyfer is a slight favorite to win.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The fight is canceled or Pyfer is removed from the card; or he competes at UFC 316 but fails to win (loss, draw, or no contest).
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Pyfer fights at UFC 316 (vs. Gastelum or a replacement) and wins by decision or finish.
forecast.rationale: Set-up: Per the linked report, Joe Pyfer vs. Kelvin Gastelum has been rebooked for UFC 316 after a prior cancellation. My research assistant notes Pyfer has won 6 of his last 7, is 4–1 in the UFC, and most recently scored a first-round KO (and bonus) over Marc-Andre Barriault. He previously withdrew from the Mexico bout due to illness. Timeline suggests UFC 316 is roughly three months away. Framework: The probability that “Pyfer defeats someone at UFC 316” equals P(he fights at UFC 316) × P(he wins | he fights). Status quo weighting: The world usually changes slowly, so I overweight the current booking: the most likely path is that Pyfer faces Gastelum as scheduled. Fight-occurrence risk: Individual UFC fights have a non-trivial cancellation rate weeks to months out (injury, illness, visa/weight issues). Three months out, I assign roughly 15–25% risk that Pyfer does not end up competing at UFC 316 at all. Conditional win probability: Against Gastelum specifically, market and stylistic priors point to a modest edge for Pyfer—power, athleticism, and momentum versus Gastelum’s experience, durability, and wrestling/pace tools. Pyfer’s loss to a seasoned grappler like Hermansson shows a path for Gastelum, so I keep the win chance moderate, around 58–62%. Replacement-opponent scenario: If Gastelum withdraws but Pyfer remains on the card, a short-notice replacement could be slightly more favorable on average, but uncertainty remains; I’d keep win odds in the low 60s in that branch. Putting it together: With ~75–85% chance he fights at UFC 316 and ~60% chance to win conditional on fighting, the overall probability sits near the high 40s to low 50s. Why not higher? Non-trivial cancellation risk plus a competitive matchup where Gastelum’s experience and wrestling could replicate the kind of problems Pyfer has faced before. Why not lower? Pyfer’s recent form, finishing upside, and the fact he’s likely the betting favorite give him the modal outcome if the fight happens. What would move me up? - Market odds opening with Pyfer at -200 or better; - Reports of Gastelum struggling with camp, injuries, or weight; - Confirmation Pyfer remains healthy/deep into camp; - A favorable stylistic replacement if the opponent changes. What would move me down? - Injury/illness news for Pyfer or indications he may be pulled/moved off 316; - Strong reports of Gastelum’s wrestling-focused camp or five-round-level conditioning trending into a three-rounder; - Odds opening near pick’em or favoring Gastelum; - Venue/conditions that disadvantage Pyfer (e.g., late-notice travel/altitude).

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Joe Pyfer defeat someone at UFC 316?

Question background:
Sports Illustrated: [UFC 316 adds rebooked fight after last-minute Mexico cancellation](https://www.si.com/fannation/mma/news/ufc-316-rebooked-fight-kelvin-gastelum-joe-pyfer-mexico-cancellation)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Joe Pyfer defeats someone at [UFC 316](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFC_316).

If Pyfer does not fight anyone at UFC 316, this resolves as No.


Your research assistant's report says:
Joe Pyfer has won six of his last seven professional fights, holding a 4-1 record within the UFC. His most recent victory was a first-round knockout of Marc-Andre Barriault at UFC 303, which earned him a Performance of the Night bonus. Pyfer had to withdraw from the originally scheduled fight against Gastelum in Mexico due to an illness.

Today is 2025-05-26.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
